dialogues.speaker: 1EXT. ABBOTT HOME
dialogues.text: (LATE SPRING, 1957)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPENING CREDITS ROLL over a TENT MONTAGE -- ASSORTED ANGLES of a group of men hard at work erecting a large striped "big-top" style canvas tent, INCLUDING: The long steel stakes being sledge-hammered into the lawn, practiced hands rapidly rigging the lines, the tall center poles being leveraged upright, the heavy rolled-up sections of canvas being maneuvered into position, and ENDING WITH the canvas being hoisted up the poles as the tent assumes its full and finished form.

dialogues.speaker: TENT
dialogues.text: -- on the front yard of the Abbott mansion. The residence is on Main Street, four blocks from where the commercial district begins. The mature, over-arching trees makes this street of prosperous houses a grand promenade.

dialogues.speaker: 2EXT. ABBOTT HOME
dialogues.text: JACEY HOLT and DOUG HOLT walk along the sidewalk on their way to school. Jacey is seventeen; he's as handsome and seemingly self-confident as his younger brother is rumpled and impulsive. Doug is fifteen, a popular culture chameleon who takes on the colors and affectations of whomever his "hero" is at the moment (which presently happens to be Elvis Presley). Jacey stops and stares with open-faced misery at the tent on the Abbott's front yard (the installation of the tent indicates that the Abbott's are having yet another of the many parties they throw every year).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't get invited, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? I'm not going and I got invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who invited you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam, I guess. I don't know. Didn't open the envelope. I mean, come on, every time an Abbott girl gets her period they have some party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kotex parties, Kotex party hats, pin the Kotex on the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Jacey swats Doug's school books out from under his arm -- Doug charges his brother to retaliate but they are rudely interrupted by a CAR HORN. They scurry out of the way as LLOYD ABBOTT pulls his 1957 Cadillac out of the driveway and cruises down the street. Lloyd is a well-dressed- and-fed man in his mid-forties. A Midwestern burgher, he exudes the status he enjoys as one of the preeminent pillars of this community. Doug is embarrassed by Lloyd's passing, but Jacey evidently experiences a deeper humiliation -- he gives Doug a glance of betrayal, turns and walks down the block.

dialogues.speaker: 4INT. HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: ELEANOR ABBOTT gathers some books from her locker. Eleanor is sixteen, outgoing, sarcastic, and very popular. She is the middle of the three Abbott daughters. Eleanor closes her locker, turns and discovers Jacey standing behind her. He follows her down the busy hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to call you last night but the line was busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was busy all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you had the wrong number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Who said I was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to talk to you last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can talk tonight at the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now you are. But if you're mad at me you don't have to come. She gives him a sultry smile, turns and glides into a classroom as the BELL RINGS. The corridor is quickly vacated by all but Jacey -- he savors the aftertaste of Eleanor's smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING ANGLE of the modest two-story clapboard house in a working class neighborhood. A home-made ping- pong table takes up so much room in the detached garage that it forced the eviction of the family car, a 1950 Plymouth coupe, which is parked nearby on the driveway. The garage doors are open and the garage light is on. We hear (V.O.) DOUG SINGING bits and pieces of "Heartbreak Hotel" in his best Elvis fashion. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                  3A/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug stands in front of the bathroom mirror (wearing a coat and tie) still singing "Heartbreak Hotel" while he carefully draws sideburns on his face with a wide-nib pen and a bottle of India ink. Jacey's reflection appears in the mirror behind Doug -- he's wearing a coat and tie too Jacey does a pained take on Doug's handiwork:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELEN HOLT is seated at the dining table. She was grading a stack of spelling tests with a red pencil when Jacey and Doug came in to ask her to adjudicate the matter at hand. She is an attractive but unostentatious woman without interest in appearing to be anything other than what she is: a forty-one-year-old widow raising two teenage sons on a school teacher's salary. (She teaches second grade at Haley Elementary School.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to wash it off, Mother. You cannot let him go to the party unless he washes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll look worse if I wash it. It's India ink, it'll turn gray, it'll look like dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like such a clown and he doesn't even know it! He doesn't get how things work in this town. I thought you weren't even going to the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, you do understand that you may be the only person at this party with artificial sideburns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do understand that your sideburns don't look real? Doug was hoping they didn't look that phony, but he conceals his disappointment and nods:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That they look, really, as though you'd drawn them on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows, then shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She looks hard at Doug for a beat, then turns to Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, darling, it seems he does understand. Why don't you just go on to the party and ignore Doug. Just have a good time and pretend you don't even... Jacey curses under his breath and storms out the front door before his mother can finish her sermon.

dialogues.speaker: 8EXT. ABBOTT HOME/TENT
dialogues.text: The curb is lined with parked cars. We hear a dance band playing "QUE SERA" and the sounds of the party as Doug lopes up the sidewalk sporting his India ink sideburns and smoking a cigarette. He flicks the cigarette into the street with well-rehearsed ease as he turns and walks up the long driveway towards the glowing "big-top" tent. Doug trails his hand over Lloyd Abbott's Cadillac, caressing it from hood-to-trunk as he ambles by.

dialogues.speaker: 9INT. ABBOTT HOME/TENT
dialogues.text: Doug enters the tent and surveys the gathering -- a tuxedoed ten-piece band plays on the bandstand. Despite his mother's advice, a nauseated grimace falls over Jacey's face when he sees that his younger brother has arrived. He is dancing with Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: 9CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They dance past a group of young men on the sidelines (Jacey's senior classmates), they are all edgy with envy, waiting like predators for their chance to dance with Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out to the lake tomorrow. Sandy wants to show-off her dad's new boat. Why don't you come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you'll just have to write me a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you wanted to talk to me in private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant... just... we never get a chance to be together, alone, you know? STEVE (one of the envious classmates) makes his move and cuts in on Jacey and dances away with Eleanor. Jacey handles it with aplomb but his true irritation at being separated from the object of his desire reveals itself as he observes Eleanor flirting with her new dance partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sampling the hors d'oeuvres. He places the ones he doesn't like back onto the platter. PAMELA ABBOTT steps over to Doug. She is his age (fifteen), the youngest of the Abbott girls, and the least stuck-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. u                DOUG Hi. She points at Doug's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like your tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   7.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doug glances down at his tie and Pam flips her index finger up across the tip of his nose. Doug scowls and points at her bust. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I borrow a Kleenex? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greaser. DOUG (mouth full of food)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any smokes around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Pam smoke their cigarettes in the back yard. The tent can be seen in the b.g. The band is playing

dialogues.speaker: "MONA LISA."
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, is this Peter guy Alice is gonna marry rich? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. He's one of the Atlas Steel Vanlaninghams. Pittsburgh. He's a bully. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come Alice's marrying him? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my parents want her to and Alice is afraid of my parents. It's practically an arranged marriage. They think Alice has peanut shells for brains or something, so they sort of suggested that maybe it was time to tie the old knot and they sort of suggested that Peter was the one to do it with. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, no one can be that much of a pushover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    8

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Alice is the good daughter, Eleanor is the bad one, and I'm the one who sort of gets off the hook. That's just the way it works. Which one are you? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, which kind of brother am I? You got me? The little brother, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band improvises a FANFARE as Lloyd Abbott and his wife, JOAN ABBOTT, step up onto the bandstand. Joan has the practiced poise of a former beauty queen (as if her smile had been surgically sewn onto her face). She has a tendency to smoke and drink a bit too much and eat and sleep a bit too little. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen -- I'd like to propose a toast in honor of our cause for celebration tonight -- the engagement of our daughter, Alice, to Mister Peter Vanlaningham. He gestures to ALICE ABBOTT and her fiance PETER VANLANINGHAM. Alice is nineteen, the eldest and the prettiest and seemingly most conventional of the three sisters. Peter is the scion of a wealthy Pittsburgh family. He and his bride-to-be smile and acknowledge the applause and AD-LIBBED toasts. The band strikes up "I Got the World on a String" and Joan whispers something to Alice -- Alice goes over to Lloyd and (despite his mock-protest) pulls him out onto the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The guests applaud their uninspired box-step; neither father nor daughter appear comfortable at such close quarters. 13       EXT. ABBOTT HOME - DRIVEWAY & TENT - NIGHT The party is going full swing as Doug wanders out of the tent and walks down the driveway. He's had enough of high society for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug strolls along the sidewalk (in a residential neighborhood) softly singing "You Ain't Nothin' but a Hound Dog." He pauses beside a rubbish can on the curb, strikes a wooden match, and sets the trash on fire. As he nonchalantly continues down the sidewalk we see several trash cans on fire in the near distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor necks with Steve (Jacey's rival) on the glider in the gazebo in the distant corner of the yard. The sounds of the PARTY can be heard in the b.g. (the band is playing "In Old Monterey"). Jacey stands in the shadows of the shrubbery spying on them with pure heartache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey walks home with his eyes brimming with bitter tears -- past the smoldering rubbish cans along the curb. 17       EXT. HOLT HOME - SIDEWALK & GARAGE - NIGHT (MINUTES LATER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jacey turns up the driveway, a light snaps on in the garage. The garage doors are open, Doug sits on the edge of the ping-pong table smoking a cigarette with his hand still on the light fixture pull chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three out of five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two out of three. You serve. Jacey and Doug pick up their paddles and begin a game of ping-pong. They are expert players and fierce competitors. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd Abbott pulls his (1957) Cadillac up to the pumps. The DING-DING of the BELL HOSE summons Jacey. He wears a Texaco uniform complete with bow tie and cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill 'er up.   Hi-test. Jacey sets the pump nozzle on automatic and cleans the windshield. Lloyd slips the ashtray out of the dash, climbs out of the car, and empties the ashtray in the trash can. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a nice party last night. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.   Eleanor invited me. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she? Didn't see you. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to be an engineer like your dad was? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be an architect. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm... I guess some people care more about having ideas that they do about making money. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care about making money. Lloyd idly examines the mechanism on the ashtray that enables it to slide in-and-out of the dash. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That full suspension file drawer your dad invented is still in production, did you know that? We'll ship thirty-maybe-forty thousand of those file cabinets this year. Hell, that drawer put Midwest Steel Desk on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.   I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An architect, huh? The GAS NOZZLE CLICKS OFF, Jacey hangs up the nozzle, and replaces the gas cap. Lloyd pulls out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some free advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't waste your life making other people rich. Keep the change. He hands Jacey a five-spot and gets into his car. Lloyd drives away in his Cadillac. Jacey crumbles the five dollar bill into a ball. As he returns to the office he catches his reflection in the mirror of the cigarette machine. He frowns and pulls off his cap and bow tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The abandoned boathouse is a dilapidated structure situated on an isolated shore of the large lake. Doug strikes a wooden match, shepherds the flame, leans over, holds the match to his ass and lights a fart. The amorphous blue flame flares and almost instantly disappears as the gas is consumed. VICTOR, Doug's partner in crime and best friend, is impressed. (Victor is fifteen, too.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez Louise!   How'd you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intestinal gas -- produced by bacterial metabolism of food residues in the colon. A mixture of oxygen, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and methane. That's the secret ingredient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so secret about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everyone can produce methane. It's genetic, that means it's inherited. There's a lot of methane in my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it up, it's all in the encyclopedia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't got farts in the encyclopedia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, they got 'vagina' in the dictionary, they got farts in the encyclopedia. The ROAR of a PASSING SPEEDBOAT attracts Doug's interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vagina is in the dictionary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'A canal leading from the uterus to the vulva'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure read a lot, man. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A canal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug steps out of the boathouse onto the   sagging dock a sees a fast speedboat cutting across the   lake towing a male water skier. (Another young man is    driving the bo with two young women in bathing suits as   passengers.) Victor comes out as the speedboat's wake   rocks the old dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assholes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Jacey -- that's him skiing. He must've skipped out on work.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDBOAT
dialogues.text: -- with Jacey skiing behind it. STEVE is at the helm. Eleanor and SANDY lounge in their bathing suits.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As they pass a ski ramp Steve points to it. Jacey gives him a thumb's up gesture and Steve circles the boat around for the approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way!   He's never done the ramp. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to do it. Steve lines up the approach and pushes the throttle open. Jacey swings out on the end of the tow-rope and pops over the wake. Eleanor leans over to Steve. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're going too fast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. The boat zips by the ramp and Jacey's skis contact the slippery surface and his skis go out from under him. He takes a hard bounce, loses hold of the tow-rope, and goes tumbling over the apex of the ramp into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey is soaking in the bathtub.   Doug enters without knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to eat. Doug washes his hands. Jacey climbs out of the tub and fetches a towel. And Doug reacts to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Jacey's back and buttocks are severely bruised. Jacey wraps the towel around his waist and turns to his brother. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't tell Mom. All right? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, all right. Jacey walks out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd Abbott's 1957 Cadillac pulls up to the pumps. Lloyd is behind the wheel, Joan sits next to him, Eleanor and Pamela are in the back seat. The DING-DING of the BELL HOSE summons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sticks the mop he's been using into a pail and goes to answer the bell. He hesitates as he sees the Abbotts and lets another attendant wait on them. He retreats into the garage and resumes mopping the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Jacey finds Eleanor standing in the garage doorway. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you got accepted to Penn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   Yeah.   Thanks. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you swing an Ivy League school like that? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandfather went there.   I had the grades, so... ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stinks in here. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dropped something.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, me. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought you and Steve... ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's what you thought. I think Steve is... I don't even know what I think about Steve, I never think about him. I just do things. And let other people figure them out. That's what parents are for. They're real good at doing all the thinking. Why should I? (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is going to have a baby. She and Kilroy didn't waste any time. He's already talking about having another, and Alice is up- chucking every hour on the hour. She's got morning-noon-and-night sickness. I've got the feeling she'll be barefoot and puking for years to come. Wallpaper patterns -- that's all she talks about. She and my mother spend hours looking at wallpaper pattern books. That's another thing I never think about... wallpaper. (another beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think this is called the silent treatment. I get enough of that from my father, I don't need it from you. Good luck at Penn. She starts to walk away, but Jacey pulls her back and kisses her fiercely -- Eleanor responds with equal heat. They don't see Pamela enter the garage. Pam studies them for an imperturbable beat, then: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Eleanor -- Dad's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbotts drive away. Jacey stands in the garage in the b.g. He watches the Cadillac disappear into traffic. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- with Lloyd behind the wheel, Joan in the front passenger seat, and Eleanor and Pam in the back seat. Lloyd says to Eleanor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I said so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family-style restaurant in the center of town. It's a sweltering, hot July day. Heat shimmers off the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decor is mock-Colonial. Victor and Doug (in their bus boy uniforms) are stocking a waitress station with silverware, coffee cups, and water glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have a party out at the boathouse, man. That's what we should do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, invite some girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some beer, go swimming. Look up a few words in the dictionary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, like 'boring' or 'eunuch.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eunuch?   What's that? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Latin for bus boy. WEBB CROSBY, the proprietor of the restaurant, steps over. WEBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business is a little light today, too damn hot. Which one of you knuckle-heads wants to get off early? DOUG & VICTOR (in unison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me... I do. WEBB (takes out a coin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it in the air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug bicycles away (he won the coin toss).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sails through the back door. He gets a bowl out of the cupboard and fetches the ice cream scoop from a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug enters with the bowl and ice cream scoop in hand. He lifts the lid of the freezer, reaches for a carton of ice cream and something startles him. He cocks his head to listen and slowly lowers the freezer lid. He peers into the silvery, dim light and sees Jacey and Eleanor naked on an old daybed near the coal bin in the back of the garage. She is on top of Jacey, riding him rhythmically. Eleanor is facing Doug. She reacts without alarm or shame when she notices Doug staring at her. She coolly returns his stare. Doug tries, but he's unable to avert his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eleanor only shifts her gaze when distracted by her orgasm, which triggers Jacey's -- as she recovers her composure she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Doug. Jacey bolts upright, throwing her off of him, and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out!!! Doug drops the bowl and scoop and charges out of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug races away from the house on his bicycle -- pumping furiously and sweating profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug dives into the lake in his underpants, then surfaces. The water has cooled his body, but not his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen assists Jacey as he packs his bags in preparation for his departure to college the next day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we forgot an umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll buy a new one in Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't forget your sport coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll go pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take Doug with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to the cleaners.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him along for the ride.   Go have a root beer at the Dog'n'Suds. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta finish packing. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll finish up. Doug's going to miss you. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baloney. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he will. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dammit, Jacey, please -- take your brother with you. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey (behind the wheel) and Doug drive into town in the Plymouth coupe. After a long silence: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Mom starts having problems with the car stalling just change the fuel filter. It gets clogged up when she lets the gas tank get too low. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every-once-in-a-while take her to the movies so she doesn't just sit around the house all the time reading. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She likes to read. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reads too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    2

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll take her to the movies. JACEY (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go have a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Root beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we gonna get beer? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bait shop. If you go in alone and nobody else is in the store, Ernie'll sell you a couple of bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plymouth is parked on a dirt lane separating two cornfields. Jacey sits on the fender of the car nursing on a bottle of beer. Doug urinates between two rows of corn. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that time I got my dick caught in my zipper? Jacey gives Doug a quizzical look. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when I was in first grade. At school? In the boys' room? Remember I wouldn't let Mrs. Horton help me, so she went and got Mom out of her classroom, but I wouldn't let Mom help me either. I told her to go get you. Remember? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doug retrieves his beer from the roof of the car. A semi-trailer drives past with "Midwest Steel Desk, Inc. -- Haley, Illinois" painted on its sides. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should own that company. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midwest Steel Desk. Dad's file cabinet drawer. Lloyd Abbott screwed mom out of Dad's patent after he died. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says who? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's not stupid. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say she was stupid. Lloyd's pretty smooth. That's why he owns the company. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owns the company 'cause he married the boss's daughter. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owns the company 'cause that patent saved the company's ass after the war, when all the war contracts dried up. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe Mom sold it 'cause we needed the money. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What money? We never had any money. Money had nothing to do with it. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did she sell the patent?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just did, that's all that matters. And that's why we're driving this car and not that one. Jacey gestures to '57 Thunderbird convertible speeding past them. He finishes off his beer, then: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you'll just have to be real careful zipping up your pants while I'm gone. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen stands on the curb waving good-bye as the Greyhound bus carrying Jacey away to Philadelphia departs. Doug hangs back, leaning against the Plymouth's fender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug steals lustful looks at Eleanor from behind his book. She is seated across the table from him. The library is filled with students poring over their assignments. Eleanor is seemingly oblivious to Doug's probing eyes. Doug allows his pencil to roll off the edge of the table. He ducks under the table to retrieve his pencil and his ruse is revealed as he stares up Eleanor's skirt at the soft triangle that her white panties cover between her parted legs. Eleanor's hand lowers a piece of notebook paper beneath the table, on it she has written: "Hi Doug!" Doug starts with panic, rears back, cracks his head on the bottom of the table, and then, as his head rebounds from the blow, he accidentally impales himself in his chin with the sharp pencil. Doug scrambles up from under the table with the pencil dangling from his chin, knocking over his chair in the process. The tranquility of the library is destroyed by the flabbergasted reactions of the students. Eleanor is momentarily concerned about his welfare, but she cannot help but laugh, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug morosely slouches along the sidewalk on his way home from school. He sports a Band-aid on his chin. Pamela Abbott pulls up alongside Doug and tails him in her 1958 Dodge Custom Royal Lancer convertible (with the top down). PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your chin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop dead. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drive. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have my license yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convertible speeds along the two-lane blacktop with Doug behind the wheel and Pamela sitting next to him. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you never ask me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For like a date, block-head. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you all the time. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scared of me or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no. I gotta job, I got school, I don't have time for dates and all that stuff. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then forget it. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like we're... you know... like I'm your boyfriend or... PAMELA (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said forget it, so forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sits on the ping pong table gazing at the daybed as he smokes a cigarette. His reverie is broken by Helen's voice calling him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug?   Dinner...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen and Doug are at the dinner table. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't smoke in the garage, darling. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't smoke in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's lots of old stuff out there, I don't want anything to catch on fire. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't smoke, Mom. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just the same, I'd prefer it if you'd smoke in the backyard. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go, gonna be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late where? He rises from the table and fidgets with his napkin. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... have a date, kind of.    It's Friday night, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.   Well, have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too. Doug walks out of the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug waits nervously for the doorbell to be answered. He's wearing a jacket and tie. Pamela opens the door and reacts with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... what do you want? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing tonight?   You want to go out? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. You're crazy. I'm baby-sitting. My folks went out to dinner with Peter and Alice and I got tricked into watching the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   Where's Eleanor? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you came over to ask me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, 'cause Eleanor isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, you know, my parents aren't here. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... maybe some other time... Alice's BABY starts CRYING O.S. and Pamela grimaces. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hell. Okay, but just for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An episode of "Death Valley Days" with commercials for 29 Mule Team Borax AIRS on the deluxe console TV. Doug sits on the sofa smoking a cigarette. Pamela sits at the opposite end of the sofa. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not like Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so... so trig and polished. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's 'trig' mean? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... handsome, sexy, sophisticated. Pipe-smokers. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I don't think Jacey smokes a pipe. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to smoke a pipe to be trig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                  26A

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm... different than Eleanor? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like... how? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like... you're smarter. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, real smart, that's why I'm baby-sitting and she's out having fun. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor's smart. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come she flunked biology?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're no Albert Einstein. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a three-point-two average. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't mean you know my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?   You might be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?   What? What? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we talking about Eleanor? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't bring her up. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, either you're mad at me 'cause you're mad at me -- or you're mad at me 'cause you like me. 'Cause that's how girls act. I don't know much, but I know that. So like which is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both. Doug exhales with bewilderment, stubs out his cigarette, then awkwardly slides down the sofa to Pamela. She holds perfectly still as Doug slowly moves his mouth to hers and kisses her. Then he concludes the kiss to check her reaction; she timidly smiles. He kisses her again with greater fervor. Doug creeps his hand up her blouse and massages her breast. Pamela struggles to suppress her surprise, which he mistakes as a sign of her approval. Emboldened by her lack of resistance, he slips his hand under her bra. Pam is shocked by the pleasure of the sensation, then alarmed by the pace of their passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug... Doug kisses her again and as they kiss he stares at a framed photograph of Eleanor amongst an assortment of family photos on the long table behind the sofa. It is Eleanor that he is thinking of -- in his mind's eye it is Eleanor's breast that he is fondling. Pamela pulls her lips from his:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me, Doug?   Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her with such ardor that she   interprets his answer to be yes, when in reality Doug   is only trying t silence her. He pulls his hand out of    her blouse and slips it under her skirt. Pam lurches    back into the sofa:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to kiss her again but she twists her head away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it... stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves him away and jumps off the sofa. Doug looks at her with breathless confusion. She turns away from him and tries to button her blouse, but she can't see the buttons for her tears. She begins to sob and runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Pamela dashes up the stairs. Doug comes out of the den looking for her. He is quite shaken:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam?  Hey... (under his breath) Oh, dammit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly mounts the stairs, wary of invading Pamela's privacy anymore than he already has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam?

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Doug finds Pamela weeping in the dark hallway, still fastening the buttons on her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I'm really sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not Eleanor... I can't go so fast.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They are both seized with fright as they hear the front DOOR OPEN below and Peter's angry voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time we go out you have to tell that same goddamn story!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam pushes Doug down the hall away from the front stairs and whispers urgently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here! Get out!

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Peter and Alice are taking off their coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accidentally brushing your teeth with Brylcreme is a funny story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut up about the fucking Brylcreme!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comes in a red-and-white tube just like a tube of Pepsodent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear me, Alice?!   Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their BABY begins to CRY (O.S.) and they find Pamela standing at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MOMENTS LATER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sneaks down the back stairs and enters the kitchen as Lloyd and Joan enter from the garage pulling off their coats. Doug ducks back into the stair landing unseen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay out of it, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice meant no harm, I think...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LLOYD (cutting her off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what you think, it's their business. Alice is a spoiled brat, but she's Peter's problem now. So just take one of your pills and go watch Jack Paar, see what he's crying about tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sticks his head out of the back stairwell and spots Peter pounding on a locked bedroom door. PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, Alice! Open the damn door! Alice?! Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trapped in the stairwell.   He hisses under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit!   Let me out of here... He notices a small window in the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug squeezes out of the small window, his legs dangling six feet above a large rose bush directly under him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug makes his way along the crowded corridor showing a few of his wounds from his emergency landing in the rose bush. He slows as he nears Pamela at her locker. She's aware of him, but pretends that she isn't. Doug hesitates as if he might say something to her, but loses his nerve and continues to mope along the hallway. Pam's disappointment is plain to see. Doug doesn't notice Eleanor and a few of her girl friends approaching in the opposite direction. As they pass him Eleanor smiles brightly and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Doug!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girls giggle, "Hi, Doug!" has become a running punchline to them. Doug is so undone by their laughter that he walks into an open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey collects his suitcase from the bus driver. He's become very much the Ivy League man. Doug waits for him beside the Plymouth across the street. As Jacey starts across the street a CAR full of young women, including Eleanor and Sandy, HONKS, and stops beside him. Jacey hops into the car and calls out to Doug:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Doug!   Get my suitcase! The car pulls away and Doug irritably fetches Jacey's bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hood on the Plymouth is propped open.    Doug assists Jacey as he replaces the fuel filter. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know when a girl's... ready? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, `ready'?     Ready for what... sex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all ready for sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might not be willing but they're ready. Just have to make them think you're the only one around who has what they need. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out what's making them itch and scratch it. If they're scared, be dependable. If they're bored, be exciting. If they're on the rebound, catch them. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you're not very dependable or exciting, you know? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretend you are. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, it's all just fake? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sex is real. They pretend they don't want it. You pretend that you care. Everybody gets what they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if you really feel something for someone? Really care for them? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were talking about getting laid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. I don't know what I'm talking about. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marquee reads: TONY CURTIS -- JANET LEIGH -- "THE PERFECT FURLOUGH" -- CINEMASCOPE -- AIR-CONDITIONED. It's Friday night -- a long queue has formed at the box office window, mostly teenagers, but some adults, too. Jacey cruises past the theater in the Plymouth, looking for... Eleanor. She chats with a group of friends standing in line. She sees Jacey, skips over, and gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd Abbott opens a bottle of Coke that he just purchased from the vending machine. His (1958) Cadillac is being fueled at the gas pumps. As he returns to his car he sees Eleanor and Jacey drive by the station in the Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey and Eleanor are copulating on a blanket beneath a canopy of tall trees near the river. Jacey is on top, Eleanor has her legs clenched around his hips. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, come on... Her encouragement inspires their mutual orgasms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey and Eleanor approach the parked Plymouth. Jacey has the blanket rolled up under his arm. Suddenly they are captured by a pair of headlights. Lloyd Abbott climbs out of his parked (1958) Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Jacey. Lloyd absorbs this information without surrendering his composure -- but Jacey cannot conceal his shock. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jacey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night. Jacey doesn't respond to the kiss Eleanor gives him, but when she places her hand on his crotch, he yanks her hand off. Eleanor walks over and gets into the car. Lloyd gazes at Jacey for a beat, then gets in the car and drives away. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug is at the table doing homework. The DOORBELL RINGS. Doug starts to get up as Helen comes out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Helen opens the screen door and finds a well-dressed woman standing in the yard with her face turned away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? The woman turns -- it is Joan Abbott. Helen is momentarily caught off balance by Joan's bristling presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan.    How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a word with you, Helen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no, I don't have time... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug spies on Joan and Helen and their curious exchange through a dining room window. Unable to hear their words he can only witness how their words are spoken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen steps off the porch and approaches Joan, who is doing most of the talking -- but Joan seems to require a certain distance from Helen and works her way to her Chrysler Town & Country station wagon parked at the c Joan grows more and more agitated as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eager to hear what is being said, Doug dashes through the living room to the front door. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan has the driver's door to her station wagon open now. Helen is on the sidewalk. Her demeanor is measured, purposefully matter-of-fact. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's necessary. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I were you I would talk to him and tell him... HELEN (cutting her off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry, Joan, I will not do that. If you have something to say to my son, then you'll have to say it to him yourself. JOAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought you would like to know what he's done. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why on earth should I believe anything you say, Joan? Joan is unable to find a quick retort, she gets into her station wagon and drives away. Helen notices a baseball lying in the gutter, she picks it up and cleans it off with her apron. As she turns to go back to the house, she finds Doug standing on the porch steps. Without warning, she expertly pitches the baseball across the yard to Doug -- it makes his hand sting when he catches it. Helen walks up to the porch. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to ask you one question, Doug, and if you have no idea, or don't want to answer, just tell me. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any sense, you think, in which Jacey has... oh, I don't know, it sounds ridiculous... corrupted Eleanor Abbott? Led her astray? Doug's mind works in several directions at once as he tries to figure out how much he should or could tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... jeez... I know that he's... that he's slept with her. But not because he's talked about it. I mean... Eleanor has lots of boyfriends. I think Jacey likes her more than she likes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (another beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go finish your homework. Doug lobs the baseball back to her and goes inside. Helen sits on the porch steps and now the true toll that Joan's visit has taken on Helen becomes apparent -- a bone-weary sadness falls over her. Her "tranquility" is not borne of happiness, it is only a means of coping with the sadness that is at the core of her being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drab, four-door Chevrolet sedan with Wisconsin license plates speeds away from town. Incongruously, the unassuming vehicle is chauffeured by an African-American DRIVER. There are two passengers in the back seat: a conservatively-dressed, middle-aged WOMAN and Eleanor Abbott. There is nothing telling about Eleanor's countenance, neither happiness nor sadness can be found on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug walks home from summer school. He pauses to watch the workmen erecting the party tent in the Abbott's front yard. PAMELA (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're going to summer school? Doug turns to find Pam at the driveway gate. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an incomplete in U.S. History. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you manage to do that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bates caught me drawing boobs on a picture of Mamie Eisenhower. PAMELA (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do things like that? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew. I just can't seem to help it sometimes. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming to the party? Doug shakes his head no. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my birthday, you know? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's going to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.     Maybe. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just come, okay? Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug pulls the Plymouth up to the pumps. He's neatly dressed in a jacket and tie. Jacey comes out of the office and leans in the car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill 'er up. JACEY (frowns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice tie. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- mind if I borrow it? Jacey puts the nozzle in the car as Doug climbs out. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you didn't like those parties at the Abbott's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you going? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just doing someone a favor.    How come you're not going? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm persona non grata. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what it means. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened with you and Eleanor? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just outlived my usefulness, that's all. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were you `useful' to her? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, use your imagination. Doug has no reply to that. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor was just looking for a way out. A way out of the whole Abbott world. And it turns out that it takes a lot to get away. It's not enough that you sleep around with boys from your world, you have to fuck boys from the wrong side of the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Like guys from Fountain Park?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean me.     She was fucking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not from the wrong side of the tracks. Jacey hangs up the nozzle and screws the gas cap back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go to that party if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're not me. We're just as good as the Abbotts. Doug hands Jacey a few dollars.   Jacey heads for the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still don't know, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Doug follows Jacey inside as he rings up the sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Dad died... Mom... had an affair with Lloyd Abbott. That's how he got Dad's patent away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it or not. I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't you go ask Mom? Ask her what happened -- ask her why she doesn't have any friends -- ask her why she's never invited to the Abbott's -- ask her which side of the tracks we live on? Jacey shoves the cash register drawer shut. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is well underway, it's a younger crowd tonight. The band plays "Fly Me To The Moon." Doug stands apart from the others. He's ill-at-ease. His conversation with Jacey resonates within him. As he looks over the gathering, he's pained to discover how easy it is to see things the way Jacey does: Lloyd holding court with a group of men in tuxedos... Joan Abbott propelling a reluctant Alice towards a group of guests Alice's age (Alice and Peter have separated)... and, finally, Pamela dancing with a handsome young man (TED). She is the belle of the ball, radiant and suddenly mature in her beautiful gown. She smiles as she sees Doug, excuses herself, and comes over to him. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.    Having fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.    Come on, dance with me. She pulls him towards the dance floor. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me I had to dance. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one dance and we'll be even. I won't have to be mad at you anymore and you won't have to be so sorry. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to be so sorry about? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not sorry? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, yeah, I'm sorry. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about what?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always do this to me. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you weren't sorry and now you say you are. So maybe I'm not sure what you're sorry about? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for what I'm supposed to be sorry about. Okay? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sorry for feeling me up? DOUG (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, come on, Pam. Dammit. For crying out loud. Forget it. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accept your apology.   Let's dance. Doug allows Pam to pull him out onto the dance floor. He feels like a dolt, but she arranges his hands on her and they begin to dance. She gazes into his eyes and smiles: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Pam is in love with Doug, she has been since they were children. Doug is mellowed by his tender feelings for her. For a golden minute they are in pleasurable bubble of true affinity. But their bubble begins to deflate as Doug sees Joan Abbott staring at them. Her disapproval is unmistakable. Doug steers Pam around the dance floor to avoid Joan's eyes, but then he sees Lloyd Abbott. Lloyd's stare is even more discomforting. Pamela senses the change in Doug's mood, but she is unaware of the cause. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Jacey home for the summer or is he just here for a visit? The mention of his brother's name at this exact moment sends a chill down Doug's spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   42

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home for the summer. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cheaper if he stays here for the summer. He can save more money for school, 'cause he doesn't have to pay rent. Money's tight, you know, we're sort of poor. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not poor, are you? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell -- you kidding? Even with Jacey working summers, my mom had to borrow against the house so he could go to Penn. I don't know where the money'll come from for me to go to college. Doug sees Joan Abbott prompting Ted to cut in on his dance with Pamela. Doug's bitterness swells. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Alice and Peter are getting a divorce. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just separated. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, you'll have to ask them. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, where's Eleanor tonight? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor's... just not here. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!    Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, everybody in town is saying something different -- she got knocked up, she ran away, your old man kicked her out. So, which is it? Ted steps over and taps Doug on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off. Ted is taken aback.   Pamela's eyes fill with tears. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you hate me so much? TED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, asshole, but... Doug spins and slugs Ted in the jaw -- sending him reeling into the other dancers. Everyone pulls away from Doug and Pam. Doug massages his fist and looks helplessly at Pamela: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall light is on but the bedroom is dark. Doug lies on his bed (still dressed). Jacey appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Jacey play another hard fought game of ping-pong in the garage. In the midst of a volley Doug says: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go to Penn like you. Jacey snorts with incredulous laughter. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the University of Pennsylvania. I think I'm going to be an architect, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Maybe we can be roommates in Philadelphia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're nuts. You'll never get accepted to Penn. Besides, Mom couldn't afford it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get a scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a four-point-0 grade average and I couldn't get a scholarship -- so, I say you got your head up your ass. Jacey skillfully manipulates the volley and wins the game with a savage return that Doug is unable to counter. Jacey smiles, puts his paddle down, and walks out of the garage. Doug quickly picks up a ping-pong ball and hits it into the back of Jacey's head. Jacey turns and shoots a perturbed look at Doug -- Doug smiles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (WINTER, 1958)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen looks over the merchandise. Doug absent-mindedly trails after his mother as he studies a large brochure about the University of Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's 'scenic design'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what context?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a minute -- it's theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: brochure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Howard Lambert Scholarship in Scenic Design for the Theatre.' It's a full ride, four years. Pays everything almost. Hell, I could do that. Just have to figure out what scenic design is. Doug looks up from the brochure and comes face-to-face with a mannequin wearing a bra, girdle, and stockings. He almost flinches with surprise and blushes profusely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait for you outside, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: THEATER
dialogues.text: It's snowing -- Doug paces to keep warm. He momentarily forgets the cold as he sees Pam and three of her girl friends come out of the drugstore across the street. The girls are in high spirits as they get into Pam's car. Two well-dressed townswomen (MURIEL and DORIS) encounter Helen on their way into the apparel shop as she steps out onto the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Muriel... Doris. The women pass by Helen with obvious reserve. Helen is seemingly unruffled by their distant responses. She observes Doug as he watches Pam and her friends drive off. Helen and Doug walk up sidewalk (towards the movie theater -- the marquee reads: KIM NOVAK -- JEFF CHANDLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you drop me off at home and take the car and go out with your friends. Go have some fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I what? Go hang out at the Dog'n'Suds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, go out -- play bridge or whatever adults do for fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read for fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- let's go see a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Helen share a bag of popcorn as they wait for the feature to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Came here on my very first date with Charlie. Saw Rosalie with Nelson Eddy and... not Jeanette MacDonald... oh... Eleanor Powell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Dad kiss you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives Doug a "look") No. (slight beat) I kissed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) All right, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SUMMER, 1959)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commencement exercises are being held in the sweltering gym to accommodate the large crowd of proud parents and family members. Doug, hot and uncomfortable in his cap and gown, is seated among his fellow graduates behind the podium. The PRINCIPAL (at the podium) announces the names of the graduates as he calls them forward to receive their diplomas.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PRINCIPAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela Louise Abbott... Pamela rises from her seat and takes her diploma. Lloyd and Joan Abbott applaud their daughter. Joan stands to take a snapshot. Alice is occupied with her restless and fussy eighteen-month-old daughter, Susan. Doug watches Pam return to her seat; she avoids his eyes. Helen is all smiles, this is a very special day for her. The chair next to her is empty. She glances behind her and sees Jacey standing in the back of the gym. Jacey idly surveys the gathering with irritable boredom. He is only there at his mother's insistence. His eyes settle on... Alice Abbott. Alice tries to quiet her CRYING eighteen-month-old daughter (SUSAN). Lloyd makes a reprimanding aside to Alice and she rises and carries Susan up the aisle. Jacey's eyes follow Alice -- she notices his stare as she passes by with Susan in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commencement is over -- the parking lot is a sea of cars slowly negotiating through the mob of celebrating graduates, beaming parents, and rambunctious siblings. As Helen slips through the crowd she is pleasantly ambushed by three (second grade) students of hers. She has a brief exchange with the children and then moves on. Helen finds herself face-to-face with Lloyd Abbott as they both attempt to pass through a narrow space between two parked vehicles. They are both caught off-guard -- there is no graceful way for them to squeeze past each other. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Helen. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Congratulations to you, too. Where's Pam going to school? LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... Christ, I forgot. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    4

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LLOYD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryn Mawr. I should be able to remember that. It costs enough. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll do well there -- a very bright girl. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Doug -- he's going to...? HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got a scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania -- scenic design -- theater. LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same school as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filling in blank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   Well.    Congratulations. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lloyd. They pass each other and head their separate ways.   Thei chance meeting has not gone unobserved: Joan Abbott has been watching them from the front seat of Lloyd's brand-new 1959 Cadillac. She pretends to repair her lipstick with her compact mirror as Lloyd slips behind the wheel. And Helen finds Jacey frowning at her. He opens the door so that she can get into the Plymouth (Doug is already in the back seat). Jacey glares at Lloyd as he walks around the car and gets in behind the wheel. Lloyd flips down his sun visor (to block Jacey's glare) and pulls out of his parking spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waitress walks across the busy diner to Helen, Jacey, and Doug at their table. Helen and Doug are eating their desserts -- Jacey is content to brood over his cup of coffee. The waitress puts their bill on the table and steps away.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Helen starts to open her purse Webb Crosby appears and picks up the bill. WEBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the house. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Webb, really -- that's not necessary. WEBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many restaurants got an Ivy League busboy? That's worth a free meal. Charlie'd be real proud of these two highbrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he would.     He'd be extremely proud. WEBB (to Jacey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take good care of your little brother in Philadelphia, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holt family drives home from the restaurant -- Jacey driving, Helen in front, and Doug in the back seat. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a wonderful night. What a wonderful day. My two Ivy League boys. This is torture for Jacey. Doug looks out the window at the striped tent in the Abbott's front yard as they pass by. A party for the "Class of 1959" is underway (as a banner on the tent proclaims). The street is lined with parked cars and busy with late-coming guests. Doug checks the rearview mirror for Jacey's reaction, but his brother keeps his eyes on the road. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never understood that tent. I wonder if they own it? I'm surprised they don't just leave it up all year long. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HELEN (CONT'D) (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd's mother was a tough old bird. She sold eggs. They had a place way out on Ditch Road near County Line. That was ages ago. Poor Lloyd had to walk all that way in to school and then back everyday. Charlie used to call Lloyd 'Egg-head' and he didn't mean smart. (another beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the mood for ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey and Doug sit on the porch steps eating bowls of ice cream. Helen rises from the porch swing and takes her empty bowl inside the house. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll have one more scoop. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ping-pong? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too hot. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go out to the lake and get a couple beers? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want to go out to the... (exhales)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit. Goddammit! Look, I don't want you in Philadelphia. I don't need you around to remind everybody that I come from Hicksville, U.S.A. So if you're going to go to Philadelphia, you're on your own, dip shit. I don't need you riding my coat tails. Christ -- why don't you get your own life? Stop being my fucking shadow. Doug digests Jacey's insult, then scoops a ball of ice cream out of his bowl with his spoon and flings the gooey ice cream into the side of Jacey's face. Doug rises and goes to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw you. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little prick! Jacey hurls his BOWL at Doug -- it misses and SHATTERS on the wall. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missed me, peckerhead. As Doug opens the screen door Jacey dives into him -- they fall into the porch swing with such force that its chains rip out of the porch ceiling and Doug, Jacey, and the swing go overboard off the end of the porch into the shrubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inside house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug?    Jacey? What was that? Doug and Jacey scramble to their feet, their clothes are ripped and disheveled. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead, dip shit! DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta catch me first, asshole! Doug takes off with Jacey in hot pursuit. A few beats later, Helen steps out onto the front porch and discovers her sons and the porch swing missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey?   Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey races up a driveway -- Doug is nowhere to be seen. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, weasel dick! Come on out, you chicken shit! A collection of GARBAGE CANS EXPLODE in all directions as Doug pops up from behind them and bolts down the driveway. Jacey chases after him, following him across the street. They pay no heed to Helen (in the b.g.) standing in their front yard, calling out to them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas Lee!     John Charles!

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD
dialogues.text: Porch lights are turning on up and down the block and the neighborhood DOGS begin to HOWL as Doug leads Jacey between two houses.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD
dialogues.text: Doug jumps up onto a tall wooden fence. He gets halfway over when Jacey leaps up and grabs him and the fence collapses, dumping them into a back yard vegetable garden.
