dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD
dialogues.text: Doug and Jacey wrestle and grapple in the muddy soil, cursing each other and crushing the rows of green crops. MRS. PORTER appears at her back door brandishing a broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git!   Stop that! You two git! She sails into combat with her broom swinging. But Doug and Jacey are unwilling to give up the fight -- they are finally separated by a strong blast of water. They sputter for breath and discover that Helen is holding the hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen sits in a lawn chair in the back yard wearing a large straw hat and reading a book. Doug and Jacey are repairing and painting the fence. Helen looks up from her book: HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That board doesn't look straight, Jacey. Come on, Doug, you've been painting the same spot for the last five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Jacey clean their hands with turpentine. Doug picks up a ping-pong paddle and bounces the ball on it, trying to see how long he can keep it bouncing. Jacey finishes cleaning up, picks up a paddle, and then, without a word, Doug serves the ball and they begin to volley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plymouth drives along the two-lane blacktop past the fields of tall, green corn. Doug is driving, Helen sits beside him. She reacts to something in the distance: HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that Pamela Abbott? In the distance Pamela struggles with a jack as she tries to remove a flat tire on her convertible. Doug grimaces as he recognizes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Pam.    Pull over. Doug reluctantly pulls over beside Pam's car. She's no more pleased to see Doug than he is to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Pam.   Do you need some help? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Holt. It's so darn hot the stupid jack just keeps sinking into the pavement. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe Doug can give you a hand? Doug frowns and slowly climbs out of the Plymouth. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the thing that goes on the bottom of the jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What thing? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing, the base that the jack fits into? (finds it in her open trunk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought that was just the 'spare-tire-holder-on-er.' DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read your manual. Pamela would slug him if his mother wasn't present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doug releases the load on the jack and strains to extract it from the molten pavement. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam, would you mind running Doug home? I'd like to get to the bank before they close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom... PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mrs. Holt, I'll drive him home. Thanks for stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.   Bye-bye. Helen slides over behind the wheel and drives away. Doug fumes silently while he reassembles the jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey sits at the counter at the rear of the busy diner sipping an iced tea. He sees Alice Abbott enter -- she pulls a dollar bill out of her purse as she approaches the cash register near the front door. She calls out to a waitress who is fetching an order from the grill. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- could I get change for a dollar? The waitress is too distracted to take notice of Alice and Alice herself doesn't notice Jacey as he steps up behind her. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I need change for... (turns to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... you don't work here, do you? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was just thinking about you. I was going to call you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                   55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   Why? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a picnic out at River Point on Sunday -- I wanted to invite you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring Susan, kids love picnics. ALICE (re: the dollar bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need change for the parking meter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Jacey opens his palm and reveals the correct change. Alice nervously exchanges the dollar bill for the coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have time for an ice tea? ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's waiting by the car so I won't get a ticket. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she'd like an ice tea, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No harm asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll make you a deal. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came in to get some change. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to the picnic on Sunday and I'll wait here and let you leave first, so your mother won't see me. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if my mother sees you. JACEY (heads for the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't care if I ask her if she'd like to join us for an ice tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!    Wait. Jacey turns to her. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can.     I'll try. It just depends. Alice goes out the door -- as she passes by Jacey he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday.     River Point.   Around noon. Jacey watches through the window as Alice returns to the Town & Country station wagon and puts a few coins into the meter. Joan waits impatiently beside the car with Susan in hand. As the Abbott women walk down the sidewalk (away from the diner), Alice glances back and sees Jacey smiling at her from the diner window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela sits behind the wheel of her convertible listening to PAT BOONE sing "April Love" on the car RADIO. Doug drips with sweat as he tightens the lugs on the spare tire. Pamela climbs out and inspects his progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    5

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you'll finish sometime today? I'm getting sun stroke. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the top up. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop acting like Jacey. What makes you think you're so... cool? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because -- I know all the answers on 'The $64,000 Question,' because I have X-ray vision and I can sing better than Pat Boone. And because I'm really a negro, but don't tell anyone around here, 'cause you know what would happen to me. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I can't even talk to you. She starts to get back into the car, then turns to him:

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name one bad thing I've ever done to you. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, name one bad thing. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me, because I don't get it! Look, I'm not rich, my father is. And I didn't pick my father. And if I had a choice between having tons of money or having another father, I'd be absolutely delighted to be poor! But unfortunately life is not a cafeteria! DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is not a cafeteria? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean! DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I'm supposed to feel sorry for you 'cause you're rich? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, am I supposed to feel sorry for you 'cause you're so poor? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then just stop it! DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop what?! PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop treating me like an Abbott! DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how am I supposed to treat you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    5

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you used to. Like just plain Pam. Doug exhales as if he's winding up to apologize. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't have to say you're sorry, and you don't have to look like somebody just ran over your dog. You just make me want to scream sometimes. Doug stares at her as if he's never seen her before. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey lounges on top of a blanket beside a cooler. ALICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is everyone? Jacey sits up and finds Alice standing behind him. She carries a picnic basket. Other than a few children skipping rock into the river they are alone. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are everyone. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said... JACEY (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't. I just said a picnic. I didn't say if anyone else was coming. Alice walks away.    Jacey jumps up and runs after her. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going? ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    5

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY (blocking her way)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't come here to see everybody else. You came here to see me. Didn't you? That's why you didn't bring Susan along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm married. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were getting a divorce? ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, but it's not final yet. Besides, I'm two years older than you. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, if the cops come around we'll tell 'em you bought the beers in the cooler.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT DAY
dialogues.text: Jacey and Alice wander along a path on the riverbank. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew he would hit me. Peter's a real hot-head. I knew if he hit me hard enough, hurt me enough, that even my father wouldn't stand for it. Then one night I put too much soap in the washing machine and it overflowed. That did it. He punched me. Broke my front tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what do you hear from Eleanor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.   Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Did you love her?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren't in love, we were in heat. Alice blushes. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you love Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you marry him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey holds open the driver's door as Alice climbs in behind the wheel (of her mother's Town & Country stat wagon). He closes the door. JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which tooth was it? She points to a front tooth.      He leans over to look a it. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one. I had it capped.       You can't really tell, can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    It's a beautiful mouth. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to kiss me? JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to scare you. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see you again, Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can.    There are ways. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... why you? Why am I telling all these things to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there's no one else you can tell them to. Because I'm the only person you know who will admit to your face that your father's a bag of shit. The biggest bag of shit in this town. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better head home. Shouldn't be gone too long. Alice drives away.   Jacey smiles -- he's won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plymouth cruises back toward town. Jacey drinks a bottle of beer and happily contemplates the possibilities of a relationship with Alice. He approaches a billboard that reads: "MIDWEST STEEL DESK, INC. -- Welcomes You to Haley, Illinois." Jacey drains the last of the beer and hurls the empty bottle at the billboard as he drives past it.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Pam's convertible is parked in a weed-choked yard. Pam and Doug hurl rocks at the windows, trying to break what is left of the shattered windows on the weather-beaten, two-story farmhouse. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you look like more, your father or your mother? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't know. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what did your father look like? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a photograph. I never knew him. He died like a month before I was even born. Jacey probably looks more like him than I do. Jacey's named after him. That's how he got to be called 'Jacey,' after his initials, John Charles, J.C.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died in a car wreck, right? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never heard about that? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was sort of a car wreck. He drowned, or froze to death, or both, I don't know. He was trying to drive out to Mud Island. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mud Island's in the middle of the lake. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was winter time, the lake was froze over. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, that's pretty stupid. (catches herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, it is stupid. Real stupid. He did it on a bet. He bet someone twenty bucks that he could do it. He made it all the way out there, too. He went through the ice on his way back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Pamela sit on the ridge of the farmhouse roof (they climbed out of a dormer window from the attic). DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think my dad was like Jacey is. Some guys are just dare-devils. I bet Jacey once that he couldn't do a back-flip off the garage roof into a big pile of leaves. And he did it. PAMELA (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One time Eleanor and I snuck out and walked around the yard naked.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was sort of a dare, too. She dared me, I dared her, so we both did it. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this day or night? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there a full moon? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walked around the yard or did you like run from tree to tree? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just walked around the yard. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front yard or back yard? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back yard. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it matter? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Back yard nudity is hypocritical. It's insincere. People should do and say exactly what they feel or think and not try to hide things. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Their conversation is stifled by this new standard of absolute honesty.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The sunset provides a convenient excuse for their silence. But then Pam realizes he is staring at her. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look pretty. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Pamela takes his hand, gently unfolds it, and with her index finger she writes on his palm, "I love you." Telling him took all the nerve she could muster, she hasn't the stamina for a disappointing response -- she places her fingers on his lips to silence him. Doug leans over and kisses her, sweetly and tenderly, and for a long time. They will always remember this kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marquee reads: "FRANK SINATRA -- EDW. G. ROBINSON --

dialogues.speaker: 'A HOLE IN THE HEAD'
dialogues.text: Alice Abbott buys a ticket at the box office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie has already begun. Alice enters the sparsely peopled theatre and pauses to allow her eyes to adjust to the darkness. A hand reaches out and takes her hand -- it is Jacey. He's seated beside the door. He rises and leads her across the row of empty seats to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey guides Alice to two seats deep in the shadows of the otherwise unoccupied balcony. They gaze at the screen for a few moments, then he moves his mouth to her ear and nibbles on her lobe. She turns her lips to his and they kiss passionately. Jacey slides his hand under her skirt. Alice presses herself against his hand and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell... don't tell anyone what we're doing... don't tell anyone... no one can know, Jacey... no one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (WEEKS LATER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station is closed and locked up for the night. Jacey and Alice are naked in the back seat of a car parked inside the dark service bay. It is a hot and humid night. They are slippery with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's impossible...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen leans out a bus window and calls to Doug, who is perched on the front fender of the Plymouth, which is parked nearby with Jacey behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to water my tomatoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mom, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls away. Doug waves as the bus goes down the street -- then he leaps with surprise as an impatient Jacey leans on the CAR HORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Pamela lounge on opposite ends of the sofa with his bare feet pressed against hers in a gentle shoving match. They are watching an episode of "Sea Hunt" on the TELEVISION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is your mom gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks. She goes up every summer to see this friend she went to college with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor lives in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's going to stewardess school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they teach you at stewardess school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    How to wiggle your bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should go there instead of Bryn Mawr? She pushes harder against his feet and her foot slips off his and clobbers him in the crotch. He moans and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oww!   Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an accident. Don't be crabby. She pulls him down on top of her. She kisses the tip of his nose then blows his bangs off his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to... go upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought maybe you were tired of just kissing? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not tired of kissing.    Are you? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but touching is nice. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are touching. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just... you know... would like to see what you look like without any clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug! DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you curious? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know what I look like without any clothes on -- I look naked. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I touch your breasts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just on the outside? PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You can kiss me.      I like lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like lips?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your lips, block-head. I like being here like this. But I'm not taking my clothes off, 'cause if we do that, you know what we'll do. And I'm too... I don't want to be like my sisters. Not if I can help it. They kiss but are almost instantly interrupted by the SLAM of the SCREEN DOOR. Doug looks up and does a surprised take as he sees Alice going up the stairs followed by Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother. He just went upstairs with your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Eleanor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela rushes out of the house with her shoes in her hand. Doug chases after her in his bare feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... hold up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I didn't know. What does this got to do with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God... what is she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it okay for you to sneak around with me, but it's not all right for Alice to sneak around with Jacey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm not Alice! And you're not Jacey! Alice is... is like my mom, they both get hurt so easy, they're like turtles without shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know my father. You don't know how he is about Jacey. He blames him for everything that happened with Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor fooled around with lots of guys, it's not Jacey's fault your dad kicked her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus! He didn't kick her out, he put her in a nut house! He shipped her off to this clinic in Wisconsin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... I thought you said she's in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is now.     They let her out a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plymouth approaches -- Jacey turns off the headlights and KILLS the MOTOR and coasts to a stop in front of the house next door to the Abbotts'. Alice gets out of the car, Jacey hurries after her, following her into her front yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice... wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the truth, you know it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it's all just... screwing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called making love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't follow me. He grabs her arm and stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spend all day, every day, just waiting and waiting to be with you, waiting to forget everything, you make me forget... but then when I get dressed and I come home, you... just... leak out of me. Leak away. I go into the bathroom and I wash you off of me and I remember everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice?!    Is that you? Lloyd's voice paralyzes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice? Alice steps out of the shadows and finds Lloyd standing at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's talking to me, Daddy. Pamela rises from a wrought iron bench in another part of the yard -- she strolls over to Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just girl talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can talk inside.     It's late. Pamela and Alice go inside the house. Jacey exhales, he is ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug hoses down the sidewalk in front of the restaurant. Pamela pulls up in her car and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking -- maybe we shouldn't see each other right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?    Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... if my father... I don't really care what would happen to me if he found out I was seeing you, but I have to take care of Alice and my mother and Eleanor, and... well, it would be hard for me to do that if I were in the doghouse, too. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, why do you have to take care of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one else will. He struggles to hold his anger and frustration in check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Sure.   See you around. Pam's composure begins to weaken, but she quickly returns to the car before she can lose control. Doug turns the hose back on. He doesn't look up as she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen rinses off some just-picked vegetables. She turns off the faucet, then pauses in reaction to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen approaches the foot of the stairs drying her hands with a dish towel. She listens for a beat, then steps out on the front porch. Doug is brushing a coat of green enamel on the repaired porch swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's upstairs with Jacey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice Abbott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is she likely to stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I wouldn't hold up dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug rinses the dirty dinner dishes in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen hears the SCREEN DOOR SLAM as she fetches a clean tablecloth from the buffet. She puts the tablecloth on the table, starts for the kitchen, then hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey stands on the porch watching the taillights of Alice's car disappear into the night. Helen appears behind the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sit on the swing -- Doug just painted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to bring her here today. She couldn't see me tonight and there was nowhere else we could go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can appreciate that, Jacey, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love her, Mother. I'm going to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do her parents know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think they should?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Alice feel the same as you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has she agreed to marry you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JACEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will. She needs time. She's frightened. It's not easy for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does hiding it from her family make it any easier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have any choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is a grown woman, she's a mother with a child of her own; if she really loves you then she should...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that matters is that I get her away from them before they find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be a party to that, Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need your help.   I'm not asking for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to find somewhere else to take Alice -- I can't have you bringing her here again. I'm sorry. She steps away from the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice comes in the front door and goes up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice? Where have you been? Susie cut her finger on the piano pedal. They're as sharp as razor blades... Joan steps into the entry hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice? Did you hear me? Susan cut her finger on the piano pedal. Alice disappears at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is almost two o'clock in the morning. Helen has dozed off in her chair with a book on her lap. She is startled awake by a loud BANGING at the front door. Helen hurries to the door and opens it. Pamela is on the porch. She is out of breath and very distraught. Her CAR is parked in the middle of the street with its lights on and MOTOR RUNNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to... Jacey comes down the stairs, pulling on his bathrobe. Doug appears on the stairs behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice took some pills, some of my mother's pills...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all right, we took her to the hospital...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get dressed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's why she sent me, she doesn't want you to come, she was afraid you would if you heard from someone else. She's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just want her to rest tonight, they said they might let her come home in a day or two. She just needs to rest. I've got to go, I'm supposed to be on my way home from the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, no! I'm warning you, just wait! I'll let you know just as soon as she can see you. Please, don't make things worse. Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela dashes back to her car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: as Jacey walks down the remainder of the stairs and watches Pamela speed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... Helen closes the front door and turns to say something to Jacey, but he cuts her off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, just leave me alone. Helen climbs the stairs, collects Doug at the top landing, and leads him away. Jacey punches his fist through a glass pane of the sheer- curtained sidelight beside the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug is mowing the front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRONE of the LAWN MOWER accompanies Jacey's pacing. His face is haggard and unshaven. He glances out the window and sees something that sends him bolting out of his bedroom. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Pam's convertible barely comes to a halt at the curb before Jacey comes charging out of the house to Pam. Doug is occupied with the lawn mower; he doesn't notice Pam and Jacey at first. (Jacey and Pam have to speak over the din of the LAWN MOWER.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the boathouse -- at the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey turns and dashes up the driveway. Doug watches Jacey jump into the Plymouth and speed down the driveway and then up the street. Doug SHUTS OFF the LAWN MOWER and walks over to Pam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Doug with tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to... for Alice's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Had to what? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Jacey I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLYMOUTH SKIDS to a stop behind the Abbott's Town &am Country station wagon. Jacey jumps out of his car and rushes into the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey discovers Lloyd Abbott waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have plans for my daughters, Mr. Holt, and they don't include you. I know you. I know you better than you know me. I know all there is to know about screwing your way into a wealthy family. I'll never let you screw your way into mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?      Where's Alice? Jacey turns and rushes out of the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey hops into the PLYMOUTH and PEELS OUT as he speeds away. Lloyd Abbott steps out of the boathouse and approaches the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey speeds recklessly back into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey skids into the driveway and leaps out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey bursts through the front door and cries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice!   Alice! Joan Abbott rushes into the entry hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?!      Alice!   Alice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, where is she?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice! Lloyd Abbott steps in the front door and drops his car keys into the silver bowl on the hall table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the police, Joan. Joan hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son-of-a-bitch! Where is she?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind you, Mr. Holt... Jacey turns and sees Alice standing at the top of the stairs. She is pale and drawn and wearing a bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me. Please, Alice, just come with me now, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you... I can't... She walks OUT OF VIEW. Lloyd steps up behind Jacey and says softly but with piercing intensity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, get out of here, you runt stud. And keep your poor-boy dick out of my daughters. Jacey turns and stares at Lloyd -- then brushes past him on his way out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey haphazardly packs his suitcases. His emotions have been spent. Helen stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why spend all night and half the day tomorrow waiting in Chicago for the Philadelphia bus? Why not just wait and take the morning bus to Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because... the sooner I get out of this fucking town the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight beat; stung) Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: HOURSHORT TIME LATER
dialogues.text: Jacey doesn't look out the window as the bus (on its way out of town) drives past the illuminated billboard that reads: "MIDWEST STEEL DESK, INC. -- Welcomes You to Haley, Illinois."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Helen sit across from each other, neither one has much of an appetite. They eat in silence for a few moments, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit... why can't he just leave them alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbotts. I don't know why... why couldn't he just forget 'em? Just pretend they didn't even exist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Abbotts didn't exist, Jacey would've had to invent them, one way or another. There are no ends of Abbotts in the world, if that's what you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96                    8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he just needs that somehow. Well, actually, I know how. She rises and picks up her plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen carries her plate to the sink.   Doug follows her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, how do you know? She sits at the kitchen table and sighs as if coming around to some central, hard truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just a wreck when Charlie died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   83

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HELEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey was almost two and I was eight months pregnant with you and... well, some mornings I'd be crying before I even woke up. Then you were born. And Jacey just got lost in there. I didn't have anything for him. Mother took him over. He'd cry or call for me, and then I'd hear Mother answer him, and I'd go back to sleep. (sighs bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've taken us away from here, gone somewhere else. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Charlie died Lloyd Abbott started dropping by on his way home from work. He felt so bad about that bet Charlie made with him at the lake. That foolish, idiotic bet. Poor Lloyd -- I felt sorry for him. He'd have a cup of coffee with Mother and me. If a doorknob had come off he'd fix it. He'd carry the garbage cans to the curb. Someone dies, people try to be helpful. But he was by here so often that people started to talk. It was fairly obvious that he wanted something more from me than just a cup of coffee. I suggested that he didn't need to stop by here so often, but... then one afternoon I was at Woolworth's, having lunch at the counter. All of sudden Joan Abbott was standing there -- screaming and yelling at me to stop sleeping with her husband, with Lloyd. I was speechless. She was gone before I could find my tongue. DOUG (stunned; almost ill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see Joan, I tried to talk to her, to put her mind at ease, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, why didn't Lloyd tell her that nothing had happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he did, but men always say that, darling. Besides, Lloyd was always having affairs. He's that type of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, Jesus... but why? Why did everyone in town believe Joan Abbott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's Joan Abbott. If you cross Joan you don't get invited to her parties -- and the Abbotts have the best parties in town. The only parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate this town. I hate the Abbotts. He slaps the back of a chair and knocks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Doug, I shouldn't have told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People still talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've never heard anyone talk about it. Not to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how did...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord... he knows too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But he thinks it really happened. Helen is overcome with tears. Doug stares at her helplessly. He's never seen his mother weep before.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: &        & 129

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus cruises along the two-lane blacktop.   Doug stare out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partygoers enter building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vintage, third-floor, railroad flat -- sparsely furnished and neat as a pin. Jacey is hosting a party. A TONY BENNETT record ("When Somebody Breaks Your Heart") plays on the hi-fi. The apartment is elbow-to-elbow with Penn men and attractive coeds from Radcliffe, Mt. Hollyoke, and Byrn Mawr. Doug sits in the middle of the sofa wedged between two coeds having separate, but equally animated conversations with two of Jacey's classmates (who are perched on the arms of the sofa). Doug wears a jacket and tie but his knack at looking out of place is intact. Jacey is apart from the others wooing a gorgeous CO-ED in a tight cashmere sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Airplanes, bridges, skyscrapers, bras, all utilize the same fundamentals of structural design... With his finger he traces the back strap of her bra beneath her sweater...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stable foundation that resists compression... His finger trails the shoulder strap of her bra...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully calculated suspension... He draws his fingertip around the outside of her breast to the lower front of her bra...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cantilevered elements to provide support. The Co-ed is bothered but none-the-less bewitched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh... you know, I'm engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm engaged in conversation with you. Jacey smiles and then kisses her. Doug is spying on them from the safety of the crowd. Jacey winks at Doug. Doug shakes his head in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: PHILADELPHIA
dialogues.text: Doug walks along the sidewalk towards the entrance of the theater carrying some rolled-up plans under his arm. He reacts as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   Hey!   Pam! Pamela Abbott walks across the quad. Pam is 19 years old now, her beauty in full bloom. Doug jogs over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come down to use the library sometimes or go shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Bryn Mawr?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very... Bryn.    I got to catch the bus back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just have to drop off these set designs -- you want to go get something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.   Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?   It's been a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem taller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: her figure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you seem... not so plain. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, dinner, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.   I have to go to this party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What party? The traffic light changes and the other pedestrians cross the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a party I got roped into going. Maybe some other time, okay? I mean it, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call -- I'm at Reed Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. Doug watches her cross the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug is revising a set design -- deeply concentrating on his task. He's startled by a KNOCK on the door. MALE STUDENT (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Holt! You got a visitor downstairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug comes down the wide stairs with a puzzled look on his face. He stops at the front desk and the student clerk points to another part of the lobby. Doug walks across the cavernous lobby and finds Pamela Abbott slumped in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you miss the bus? Pam laughs and Doug suddenly realizes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, you're drunk. Awww, man... I better get you out of here before the Puritans tar-and-feather you. Can you walk? Pam awkwardly rises and Doug guides her to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me -- go out the front door, turn right, go around to the side of the building and wait for me by the fire escape. Okay? Just wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela leans against the side of the building as the fire escape ladder descends to the pavement. Doug climbs down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- up we go.   Pam? Pam keels over and vomits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam sits on the bed as Doug pulls her stained turtleneck sweater off over her head (she's wearing a bra).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you drinking, Sterno?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cold...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, we got to get your pants too. Can you stand up. (as she collapses on the bed))

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you can't stand up. All right. He undoes the waist of her pants and tugs on her pant legs, but her panties start to slide off along with her pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, nope, let's keep the panties on, okay? Pam? Can you hold on to your underpants? (she's out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hold on to your underpants. He holds her panties in place while he struggles to get her pants over her hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug rinses out Pam's clothes in a sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam's wet clothes have been draped over the radiator. Pam is passed out, tucked in under the covers. Doug sits on the edge of the bed gently cleaning her face with a damp washcloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug   stirs from his sleeping spot on the floor (he slep with   his clothes on). He notices that Pam's clothes hav been   removed from the radiator. He sits up and finds that   the bed is empty. She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela approaches her dorm carrying an armload of books. She starts up the steps then stops when she sees Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.    That's it? You're sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly alarmed) Oh Jesus... did we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-Jesus-did-we what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we... do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... don't... remember...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit. Well, I know you might find this hard to believe, but I don't sleep with drunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away.      She calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug?    Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug lounges on his bed reading a textbook. It is raining outside. He is startled by a TAPPING on the windowpane. Pamela is outside on the fire escape. He ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug! Open the window!     Come on, I'm freezing. Doug...! He gets out of bed, unlatches the window, then returns to the bed and his book. Pamela opens the window (with difficulty) and climbs in. She drapes her wet coat over the radiator and sits in the desk chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you feel like you're gonna puke use the wastebasket there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I am so sorry. I was embarrassed. I didn't know where I was when I woke up. I felt like I was dying, so, I just... I was going to call you. Doug doesn't respond -- he turns the page of his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I was blotto. I mean, I was so happy to see you. Then I just got sad. I got sad. And stupid. It happens, you know? Doug snaps his book shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hear something stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was cleaning you up, wiping the puke off your face, I suddenly realized how much I miss you -- how much I love you. How's that for stupid? Pam is stung by his flippancy, she begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you crying for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.   But it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's too screwed up. Doug kneels in front of her and anxiously tries to console her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it's not too late. It's perfect timing. We're on our own now. No Jacey and Eleanor or Jacey and Alice. That's what stinks about being the youngest, we have to sweep up after everybody else. But now it's just us. It's our turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be in love with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be in love with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I've always have been. You... block-head. He kisses her, then he gazes at her and strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: PHILADELPHIA
dialogues.text: Doug and Pam hurry along the rain-swept sidewalk towards the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large theater is dark except for a single work light standing on the bare stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    9

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doug leads Pam by the hand down the aisle from the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show you something. He escorts her up a short flight of steps and positions her center stage near the footlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stand right there. He takes the work light with him as he walks off stage. Then with a METALLIC CLANK everything goes dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right -- don't move! Stay put. There's the RUMBLE and SQUEAK of a piece of SCENERY being rolled onto stage -- then the SWOOSH of a backdrop being lowered from the fly loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost, almost... hold on. We hear Doug RUNNING somewhere backstage then a beautiful sunset slowly illuminates the stage -- creating the perfect mood for the modestly scaled stylized set that Doug has put into place: It is the roof of a weathered farmhouse with a dormer window and a tall brick chimney. Doug steps on stage, he's a bit winded from his quick- change routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Doug, it's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The senior acting class does scenes from different plays, they invite everybody, it's a real big deal. So, there's this competition among all the theater design students to do the sets. And -- anyway -- I'm the one whose design got picked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scene is it for?     What play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tad embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm... Romeo and Juliet. It's something different, I think that's why they picked it. Everybody else was doing castles and stuff. Rooftop Romeo and Juliet by Douglas L. Holt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like building models when I was a kid. It's fun. It's... make-believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, they tore that old farmhouse down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.     Did they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They always tear down the wrong stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, I missed you -- so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missed you, too. They kiss -- then Pamela pulls away.    Doug studies her, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a boyfriend, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what? You worried what your old man would think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't care what I do, as long as I don't do it in Haley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't... do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I mean... okay. We don't have to go so fast. Shit, I'm sorry. I blew it again, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Pam climbs down off the stage and starts up the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on probation. They pulled a bed-check the night I was here. I have to be back in the dorm by ten. Gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about tomorrow? I could come up in the afternoon and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! It's just too late. It's all messed up. I can't seem to make things all right. The more I try the worse everything gets. I'm sorry. Pam walks up the aisle and disappears through a door to the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam!   It's not too late!

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: &       & 145 INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: &        & 147

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam enters the lobby. A female student CLERK (#1) displays a message as Pam passes by the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam -- some guy named Doug keeps calling for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pam ignores the Clerk and the message and goes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela approaches her dorm. She stops as she sees Doug waiting beside the entrance. She turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug still waiting beside the entrance for some sign of Pam. He's tired, cold, and hungry. He grinds out his cigarette with his heel and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacey sits in his favorite armchair reading the Sunday newspaper. Doug sits in the middle of the sofa. Jacey scrutinizes his brooding younger brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boiling water KETTLE starts to WHISTLE (O.S.) -- Jacey goes into the kitchen to tend to it. There is a soft KNOCK on the front door. Doug goes to answer it. He opens the door and finds Pamela standing there with her coat in her hand. He is pleasantly surprised; Pam is distant, slightly off-balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know I was here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want another cup of... Jacey steps out of the kitchen and frowns when he sees Pam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to come by on Sundays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot. The breath goes out of Doug as if he'd been struck in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, why didn't you call first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't have any nickels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't expect to see you again. You want to fuck? I mean, that's why you came over, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take off your clothes. Pamela drops her coat on the floor. She pulls her sweater off over her head. Doug's anguish is as great as Pamela's humiliation. He cannot bear any more if this -- he walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug comes out of the apartment house and walks up the sidewalk. Tears begins to stream down his face. He begins to run and run as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Doug enters the dormitory and starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug... Doug turns and finds Jacey at the foot of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Doug continues up the stairs -- Jacey pursues him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you felt about Pam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apologize to her, you asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran into her a few weeks ago at a party. She was drinking and I... it was easy. She felt guilty about telling her father about Alice and me. Actually, I made her feel guilty, I made her feel like she had betrayed Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't betray Alice! She was just trying to get rid of you so Alice wouldn't try to kill herself again. Jesus Christ, you shit- head, Alice couldn't marry you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.    I mean, I do now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what the hell did Pam ever do to deserve your revenge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just your way of evening the score with Lloyd Abbott, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Doug spins and delivers a wild, roundhouse punch that lands brutally on the side of Jacey's face -- the impact knocks him down onto the steps. Jacey's eyebrow has split open, he is blinded by blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know   you! I don't know who the fuck   you are! You fuck everything.    You fuck everything up! Why did    you have to fuck Pam, too?! Doug walks away, leaving Jacey sitting on the steps, clutching a banister for support. He presses his palm to his eyebrow to squelch the flow of blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug approaches Pam's dormitory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug steps up to the female student CLERK (#2) at the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela Abbott, please.     Tell her Doug is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She left... last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did she go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did she go home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one seems to know. She just took some clothes and left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lost)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... no... His pain is so clear that it spurs the Clerk's sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not supposed to do this, but... well, I can give you her home address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes with irony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Yeah, right... (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean... thanks. Thanks anyway. I know her home address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbott house is decked with snow. Doug sits    behind the wheel of the Plymouth. He's parked down the    street He smokes a cigarette and stares at the house --   the pavement outside the driver's window is littered   with butts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice comes out on the street laden with packages and shopping bags. She's startled by Doug when he falls in beside her and follows her down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Pam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she with Eleanor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't find Eleanor's name in the Chicago phone book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's unlisted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you know Eleanor's address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't know her address, I don't know her phone number. You'd have to ask my father for it. All right? Alice turns and steps into another shop -- leaving Doug behind on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERRY COMO SINGS "The Little Drummer Boy" ON the TELEVISION. Doug rises from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is peeling apples to make a pie.   Doug enters and studies her for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look... tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do wish Jacey had come home for Christmas. Maybe that's what's wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that free-lance drafting job was too good for him to turn down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's why he didn't come home. I wrote him a letter, you know. About Lloyd and me. Has he mentioned it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Doug wants to avoid the topic of Jacey.    He opens the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you start drinking beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... I bought those for you. I had them in the basement; I kept forgetting to bring them up. He does a bemused take on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, I know you drink beer. Doug takes out two bottles of beer and opens them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.   Have one with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought those for you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not good to drink alone, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   Sit down.   Have a beer.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pulls out a chair for her. She reluctantly comes over and sits down. Doug sits and proposes a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. (takes a sip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's drink 'em all. Helen laughs girlishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie was always trying to get me to drink beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you always call him Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ever say 'your father'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I do, don't I? I don't know. When I think of him, I think of 'Charlie.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever... meet anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean another man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everyone always thinks things are more possible than they are. I mean, single men don't stay in Haley if they have any starch. The only eligible man around was Drew Carter, but he smells like his dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 2/16/96

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her remark cracks Doug up -- Helen laughs, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I'd remembered the beers sooner. It's nice to see you smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be.   Everyone has sad times. Doug dissolves into tears. He lowers his head and shields his eyes with his hand. Helen leans over and strokes his hair. After a few moments, he rises and wipes away his tears with a dish towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a secret. I did have a friend. A man in Chicago. I used to see him when I went up to Chicago to visit Bea during summer vacations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Used to see him' -- you don't see him anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a wonderful man. A little boring, but really, very wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long did this go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About eight years or so, it was when you boys were still at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a long time. Did you ever think about marrying him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He proposed.   But, well, obviously, I said no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm in love with... your father. With my memory of him. He was the one for me. Oh, I don't know... there's different kinds of love, darling. Some people you love no matter what. Other people you love if the situation is right. To me the best kind of love is the 'no matter what' kind. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I am a cheap drunk, aren't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus cruises along the narrow ribbon of pavement.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE BUS
dialogues.text: -- sitting by himself; there's not many passengers today. We hear the VOICES of rambunctious CHILDREN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (LATE SPRING, 1960)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second-grade students are in the midst of an art project where they make a design by gluing various sorts of dried beans to colored paper -- but the beans are being thrown about the room and other beans have been spilled on the floor. Helen wearily attempts to rein in the unruly children:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much noise, please. Let's finish up. Keep the glue on the paper. Sam, Lillian, Jack -- in your seats, please... Helen suddenly loses her energy and interest in policing the children. Their hijinks continue as she steps out of the classroom. INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Helen steps over to a window and stares out -- lost in her own thoughts and oblivious to the NOISE from her classroom.

dialogues.speaker: SPRING, 1960
dialogues.text: Doug is on a cat-walk in the fly loft high over the stage floor. He strains as he drops 20 pound slabs of pig-iron onto a counterweight carriage, then he releases the line and flies a canvas backdrop up into the loft. He locks off the line, wipes his brow, turns, and finds Jacey standing behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-the-hell do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sits in an almost empty terminal waiting to catch a red-eye flight to Chicago. A group of just arrived stewardesses pass by chatting with a captain and other flight officers. Eleanor Abbott does a take on Doug, steps away from her co-workers, and doubles back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Doug!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug almost doesn't recognize her. She is twenty years old now and very grown-up, very stylish in her stewardess uniform. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your chin? (as he doesn't respond) Remember... the pencil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    I have a little scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going home? Back to Hole-in- the-Ground, Illinois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   10

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ELEANOR (taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. Oh no. Oh, Doug, I'm sorry. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had cancer. I just saw her Christmas. She was tired, but I thought she just had the flu or something. She didn't tell us. The hospital told Jacey when they called him. ELEANOR (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Jacey? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had to stay to take his state board exams. He's coming back the day after tomorrow. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an architect? DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he passes his exams.   He will. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Doug. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I tried to find your phone number a couple of months ago. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in my roommate's name, I've got to fix that. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering if you knew where Pam was? ELEANOR (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   I don't. DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She left school. ELEANOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.   My father called me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was looking for her. I don't know where she is. I gotta run -- I'll miss my ride to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Pam I love her. Eleanor looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her... just tell her that. Eleanor doesn't reply.   She turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distance between Jacey and Doug is telling, as is the difference in their behavior. Doug leans against a wall with his hands in his pockets, his eyes cast down on his shoes. Jacey roams the alley unable to stand still for grief. He lights a fresh cigarette off the butt of another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?   Why didn't she tell us? The FUNERAL DIRECTOR appears in the back door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen's closed casket is surrounded by floral tributes. Doug and Jacey enter from a door near the casket -- they pause in reaction to the crowded parlor, it overflows with mourners. Jacey explodes under his breath, so that only Doug can hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking hypocrites -- every one of 'em. Jacey turns and walks out through the door they came in. Doug walks over to his seat in the front row -- he hesitates when he sees Lloyd Abbott standing in the back of the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sits at the table wrapping dishes in newspaper. Jacey comes in with a framed photograph of their grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want this picture of Grandma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jacey steps out of the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LATER
dialogues.text: Jacey is packing Helen's things.   Doug steps in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starving. You want to go get something to eat? Jacey is caught a bit off-guard by Doug's invitation, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
