dialogues.text: Jacey and Doug are seated in a window booth.      They ea silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to stick around.     I can handle things here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate Penn.   Always have.   You were right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should live my own life. Stop being your shadow. I'm not like you, Jacey -- I don't want to be like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to stay here?   In Haley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was thinking New York. If I'm going to really learn how to design sets, that's the place to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have to get stitches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My eyebrow -- yeah, ten stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Doug takes an envelope out of his coat pocket and puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found this in one of the boxes in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter of agreement between Lloyd Abbott and Dad. Dad sold him the file drawer patent -- not Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jacey opens the envelope and studies the yellowed document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:   document)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... he sold the patent for a used car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used cars were the only kind of cars around. The war was on -- everything was mobilized. They stopped making new cars, they were making tanks and bombers in Detroit. And even Midwest Steel wasn't making desks, they were making ammo boxes and mortar shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get to be such an expert on World War Two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U.S. History -- high school. I should be an expert, I had to take the damn class twice. I guess Dad needed a car and he figured who- the-hell needed a full-suspension file drawer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '1937 Desoto coupe convertible as is.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder whatever happened to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He parked it at the bottom of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug follows Jacey to the door of the bus. Neither one of them knows how to say good-bye, after an awkward beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting back tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Don't stand here and wave good-bye... it makes me think of Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   See you. Doug turns and walks away.   Jacey climbs onto the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug drives home from the bus depot in the old Plymouth. He slows as he sees... the party tent in the Abbotts' front yard (with its canvas sides rolled up). Susan's third birthday party is underway, dozens of well- dressed children and their parents are in attendance. Alice (who is very pregnant) and Peter Vanlaningham and Lloyd and Joan Abbott watch Susan riding her new pony, a gift from her grandparents. A new generation of Abbott parties has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "For Sale" sign has been placed on the front yard. Doug pulls up the driveway in the Plymouth. He turns OFF the ENGINE but doesn't get out of the car. Then he STARTS the CAR again and backs out of the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite it being a birthday party for a three-year-old, this is very much a grown-up affair. The band is playing, the adults are dancing, Joan Abbott is flitting from guest-to-guest, Alice is dutifully silent while Peter dominates the talk at their table, Lloyd is with his cronies. Doug enters the tent -- one-by-one the guests take notice of him as he works his way across the tent -- and all are very aware of his uninvited presence by the time he reaches Lloyd Abbott. Lloyd scrutinizes Doug, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug follows Lloyd into the dark-paneled room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the door. Doug closes the door.   Lloyd lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know your mother at all if you think someone like me would've ever stood a chance with someone like her. That just goes to show you how stupid this town is -- that they'd believe she slept with me. That'd make Charlie laugh. Your old man was my best friend. He used to call me 'Egg-head' -- hell, everybody did. And back then everybody knew that Egg-head Abbott didn't stand a snowball's chance in hell with Helen Riley. Of course, that was all before I became Lloyd Abbott -- Mr. Abbott. That was back when I still had chicken shit on my shoes and twelve cents in my pocket. Charlie Holt was the only one good enough for Helen. I used to spy on 'em -- yup, I did. (fixes a drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to watch them sit on the front porch of her house -- your house -- and watch 'em talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                   11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And talk. I never knew what to say to a girl. Never could just talk. Could dance, could listen to the radio. But I couldn't talk... except with your mother, except with Helen. I talked more to her after your dad died than I'd ever talked to any woman before then -- or since then. Jesus, I talked. Just like this. Just like right now. Just pouring out. Helen would listen and whatever I said, she'd never make me feel bad or ignorant or guilty. I mean... for Christ's sake, she never blamed me for what happened at the lake, for letting Charlie drive out on that ice. She never did anything but try to make me hurt less and I... Lloyd is startled by Joan as she opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for Susie's birthday cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit, Joan, go way! Get the hell out of here! Leave me alone! He hurls his GLASS at her and it SHATTERS on the door jamb. Joan recoils in dumb-founded shock and backs out of the doorway. Lloyd fumes over and slams the door shut in her face. He leans against the door and catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted sons -- isn't that funny? I wanted sons and I got three daughters. I wanted a woman I could talk to and I got a woman whose ears are stuffed full of money and Percodan. But I got the chicken shit off my shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96                    1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shoes are clean. (slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's what Jacey thinks. I could always tell by the way he looked at me -- even when he was a little boy -- like I owed him something. But, goddammit, he's wrong. That bet was your father's idea and I never meant your mother any harm. I would've done anything for her -- anything. I loved her. But the only thing she ever wanted from me was just for me to leave her alone. He pours himself a fresh drink, then turns to Doug:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to find Pam -- and you're going to tell me where she is.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Doug navigates the busy sidewalk to the entrance of the building. He checks the number over the door to the address on the scrap of paper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (MINUTES LATER)
dialogues.text: Doug knocks on the door. Eleanor opens it, she's dressed for work in her stewardess uniform. She's obviously surprised to find Doug on her doorstep, but she greets him with a warm smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: SIDEWALK
dialogues.text: Pamela dresses a mannequin in the display window. As she moves behind the mannequin to fasten a garment she sees Doug standing on the other side of the glass watching her from the sidewalk. Doug writes a message on the plate glass window with his index finger (printing the letters in reverse so that the message is legible from Pam's POV); his message reads: "I love you." INVENTING THE ABBOTTS - Rev. 3/20/96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MOMENTS LATER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela comes out of the store via the revolving door and finds Doug waiting for her on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever... forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always loved me no matter what I did, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that's how I love you -- no matter what. That's the best kind of love, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... oh, Jesus... how do we start all over again? Pam's eyes fill with tears. Doug steps over to her and embraces her tenderly, holding her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.   We're doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through her tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starting over.     So, what are you doing tonight?     You want to go out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people never change. He wipes her tears from her cheeks with his fingers, then gives a short, but sweet, kiss. Then he smiles:

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DOUG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. PAMELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE END
